author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Double Duty
description: Does Tracy Gray have to repeat herself? Yes, yes she does, in this puzzle.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: The Israeli hostage whose body was returned Saturday had spoken of feeling unsafe.
description: Elad Katzir, the Israeli hostage whose body was recovered and returned to Israel on Saturday, had long felt unprotected living along Israel’s border with Gaza.
content: Elad Katzir, the Israeli hostage whose body was recovered and returned to Israel on Saturday, had long felt unprotected living along Israel’s border with Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: Hillary Clinton Returns to Wellesley, but the Homecoming Is More Complicated
description: Pro-Palestinian demonstrations surrounded an appearance at a new research center named after the former secretary of state and presidential nominee at her alma mater.
content: Hillary Clinton returned on Saturday to her alma mater, Wellesley College, to celebrate the opening of a new research and study center that bears her name, more than half a century after she graduated and set off on the path that would make her its most famous alumna.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Sickened by U.S. Nuclear Program, Communities Turn to Congress for Aid
description: In St. Louis and around the country, people harmed by the drive for an atomic bomb have been shut out of a federal law enacted to help such victims.
content: When Diane Scheig’s father, Bill, came home from work at the Mallinckrodt factory in St. Louis, he would strip down in their garage and hand his clothes to her mother to immediately wash, not daring to contaminate the house with the residue of his labors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: I Hired an Agent to Sell My Home. Do I Have to Pay the Buyer’s Broker Now?
description: The legal settlements roiling the real estate industry are changing the way commissions get paid. But the change could come slowly.
content: Q: I recently signed a contract with Compass to have them represent me in the sale of my Manhattan apartment. The contract provides for a commission of 5 percent, which includes the commission for the buyer’s agent. Does the recent news about real estate commissions and which party pays them mean that I can demand to pay only 2.5 percent to Compass as my agent, and then negotiate with the buyer or the buyer’s agent regarding that person’s commission?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Quinley
title: Challenged by Uprising, Myanmar Junta Cracks Down Harder
description: The country’s military rulers have signaled a new wave of detentions and, rights groups say, conditions for existing prisoners have deteriorated.
content: Thousands of innocent people killed. Tens of thousands more pro-democracy protesters locked up. The return of military rule has wreaked havoc in Myanmar in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: To Live Long and Prosper, Do What George Takei Does
description: For the “Star Trek” actor and author of the new children’s book “My Lost Freedom,” it’s all about green tea and antioxidants. “I drink it every day, all day. I am an addict,” he says.
content: When George Takei talks about his childhood, he speaks of both anguish and beauty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Kirchick
title: Joe Lieberman and David Mixner, Exemplary Outsiders
description: Their experience of being outsiders deeply affected their political worldviews and caused them to embrace the struggles of other excluded Americans as their own.
content: The gay activist David Mixner and Senator Joe Lieberman died last month at the ages of 77 and 82, respectively, and were it not for the coincident timing of their passing, I would have no reason to reflect collectively upon their legacies. Biographically, ideologically and temperamentally, they were very different men, and to my knowledge, never interacted. But I was fortunate to know them both, and after attending their funerals last week, I’ve come to appreciate some important qualities they shared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Battle for the House: These Are the Races to Watch
description: Democrats are targeting incumbent Republicans in a number of districts President Biden won in 2020 — but the general rule is, as goes the presidential race, so go House races.
content: Control of the U.S. House of Representatives, at this point in the election cycle, is anybody’s guess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva
title: Pardoned for Serving in Ukraine, They Return to Russia to Kill Again
description: Recruiting convicts for its army has given Russia a manpower advantage. But it is backfiring in tragic ways when former inmates are pardoned and return home to commit new crimes.
content: Viktor Savvinov had already been imprisoned several times for various crimes — including robbery, auto theft and assault — when he murdered a female drinking companion during a quarrel in 2020, stabbing her in the chest with four knives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernhard Warner
title: The Economic Paradox of the Biden Presidency
description: Employers have been adding jobs since Joe Biden took office, but will the good news translate into votes?
content: One of the more puzzling aspects of the U.S. economy is that employers have been on an almost uninterrupted hiring spree since President Biden took office — and analysts see no signs that the trend will reverse any time soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom and Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: New York City Set to Pay a Record $28 Million to Settle Rikers Island Suit
description: Eight correction officers and a captain stood by for seven minutes and 51 seconds as Nicholas Feliciano tried to hang himself in a jail cell in 2019.
content: New York City has agreed to pay more than $28 million to settle a lawsuit filed by the family of Nicholas Feliciano, who suffered severe brain damage after he attempted to hang himself in a Rikers Island jail cell as more than half a dozen correction officers stood by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Help Ukraine Hold the Line
description: House Speaker Mike Johnson should allow an aid package for Ukraine to come to a vote.
content: After more than two years of brutal, unrelenting war, Ukraine is still ready and has the capacity to defend its democracy and territory against Russia. But it cannot do so without American military assistance, which the United States had assured the Ukrainians would be there as long as it was needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé and Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: A Niche Indian Actress Is Thrust Into Hollywood’s Spotlight
description: Sobhita Dhulipala has taken on risky roles in her acting career, outside of India’s blockbuster hits. Now, she’s starring in Dev Patel’s “Monkey Man.”
content: Sobhita Dhulipala considers herself an outsider — wherever she is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde Haberman
title: Mary Ann Zielonko, Partner of Kitty Genovese, Dies at 85
description: The murder of Ms. Genovese, and her neighbors’ reaction to it, generated headlines. The nature of her relationship with Ms. Zielonko was a different story.
content: For 60 years, Kitty Genovese has endured as a symbol of big-city apathy, the victim not only of a knife-wielding killer but also of her neighbors’ reluctance to get involved. Two weeks after a man named Winston Moseley stalked, raped and murdered her in Queens late at night in March 1964, a New York Times article reported that 38 of her neighbors had heard her cries for help, yet did nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Patrick McGeehan
title: Is New York City Overdue for a Major Earthquake?
description: Seismologists said that severe earthquakes are relatively rare around the city and cannot be predicted. But if one were to hit, it could inflict serious damage.
content: The earthquake that hit the Northeast on Friday morning rattled nerves but did not do much damage. Still, it left many New Yorkers wondering how afraid they should be of a bigger one hitting closer to the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel says it recovered the body of a hostage who was taken from a kibbutz on Oct. 7.
description: Elad Katzir lived near the border with the Gaza Strip. His sister said Israel’s government should have done more to get him back alive.
content: Israel’s military said on Saturday that it had recovered the body of a man who was taken hostage from one of the communities hardest hit during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack, almost six months to the day after his abduction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Daniel P. Jordan, Monticello Leader in Changing Times, Dies at 85
description: He expanded the educational mission of Thomas Jefferson’s plantation. He also embraced research that showed Jefferson had fathered the children of one of his slaves.
content: Daniel P. Jordan, who as president of the foundation that owns Monticello, Thomas Jefferson’s plantation in Virginia, broadened its educational mission — and, perhaps most significant, commissioned a study that found that Jefferson had almost certainly fathered six children with Sally Hemings, one of hundreds of people he enslaved — died on March 21 in Charlottesville, Va. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: The Condiment Wars Come for Chile Crisp (or Crunch)
description: David Chang’s Momofuku company is waging a trademark battle for the term “chile crunch.” But what does ownership mean for such an everyday pleasure?
content: It’s hard to pinpoint exactly when we reached peak chile crisp in the United States, but if you were to inspect my kitchen today you’d see, alongside an old jar of Lao Gan Ma — years ago, the only chile crisp I could easily find in the food shops nearby — at least a half-dozen others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Consumers Hate ‘Price Discrimination,’ but They Sure Love a Discount
description: The Wendy’s debacle is a warning shot for brands: If you want to play with prices, make sure to communicate why and whom it could help.
content: It’s been a strange and maddening couple of years for consumers, with prices of essential goods soaring and then sinking, turning household budgets upside down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Minor Crimes Division
description: Lessons learned, and not, from breaking the rules.
content: People taking it upon themselves to solve the tiny, overlooked crimes of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan and Maansi Srivastava
title: Looking for Wedding Dresses With a ‘Bachelorette’ Star
description: Charity Lawson, who met her fiancé on the most recent season of “The Bachelorette,” prepared for her nuptials at New York Bridal Fashion Week.
content: Charity Lawson earned a reputation of being a sweetheart after starring in the 20th season of “The Bachelorette,” which ended in August with her engagement to Dotun Olubeko, an integrative medicine specialist.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Regulating Opioid Prescriptions
description: Pain management is an inexact science; there is plenty of blame to go around for the abuse of such drugs.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Graffiti Goes From Eyesore to Asset
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 6, 2024.
content: “Hipsters attract more hipsters who have more money and are able to start paying higher prices.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Kate Coleman, Who Documented the Bay Area Counterculture, Dies at 81
description: She wrote about politics and the patriarchy as a left-wing writer, then alienated her compatriots with exposés critical of the Black Panthers and the environmental movement.
content: Kate Coleman, an iconoclastic Bay Area journalist who began her career as a left-wing radical, writing about the patriarchy, politics and polyamory, then made enemies among her erstwhile comrades when her reporting cast a harsh light on the Black Panthers and the environmental movement, died on Tuesday in Oakland, Calif. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Pro-Russia Candidate Wins Slovakia’s Presidential Election
description: The victory for Peter Pellegrini, an ally of Slovakia’s populist prime minister, strengthens Central Europe’s ties to Moscow.
content: Voters in Slovakia on Saturday strengthened the grip of Russia-friendly political forces in Central Europe, handing victory in a presidential election to a candidate who opposes providing military and financial aid to Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John White, Wendy Dorr, Sonia Herrero, Wesley Morris, Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Your Solar Eclipse Soundtrack
description: Songs to put you in the mood.
content: This Monday a total solar eclipse will appear across much of North America. Our critics Wesley Morris, Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz put together a music playlist that’s a perfect accompaniment for watching the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Why Are People Obsessed With TV Finales ‘Sticking the Landing’?
description: As “Curb Your Enthusiasm” gets ready to exit, it’s time to let go of the idea that a story’s ending determines its final score.
content: Larry David is just fine with how “Seinfeld” ended. OK, I can’t read his mind — but “Larry David,” the version of himself he plays on “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” is cool with that much-maligned finale. He insisted on it, vehemently, during a season of “Curb” that was almost entirely about a fictional do-over of the landmark sitcom he created with Jerry Seinfeld.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Rusesabagina
title: My Story Was Told in ‘Hotel Rwanda.’ Here’s What I Want the World to Know Now.
description: For me and for so many Rwandans, the 1994 genocide remains the focal point of my life.
content: This week, the world will again turn its eyes toward Rwanda. April 6 marks 30 years since the start of one of the most horrific events in modern history, the 1994 Rwandan genocide. Nearer in time but not unrelated, it has been just over one year since I left Rwanda and returned to the United States, released from prison after 939 days in captivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: From the Horror to the Envy of Africa: Rwanda’s Ruler Holds Tight Grip
description: Thirty years after a devastating genocide, Rwanda has made impressive gains. But ethnic divisions persist under an iron-fisted president who has ruled for just as long.
content: Blood coursed through the streets of Rwanda’s capital, Kigali, in April 1994 as machete-wielding militiamen began a campaign of genocide that killed as many as 800,000 people, one of the great horrors of the late 20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Biden Waves His First-Term Résumé at a Skeptical America
description: With increasing urgency, the president is trying to impress upon voters that he has accomplished quite a bit — even if they don’t see it in their lives yet.
content: President Biden is discovering that passing one of the most ambitious legislative agendas in recent American history may have been the easy part. Persuading Americans that he deserves a second term may be far more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: Pete Rose Cooperated With the Author of This Book Until He Didn’t
description: Keith O’Brien’s “Charlie Hustle” tracks the great ballplayer’s historic career and also tells a story involving gamblers, gangsters and drug addicts.
content: It isn’t easy mustering sympathy for Pete Rose. He was a compulsive gambler who bet on the team he managed, the Cincinnati Reds, then lied about it for years (he was also a compulsive liar). He had a sexual relationship with a teenage girl, and barely acknowledged the child he had with another woman out of wedlock. He was a self-pitying sore loser who abandoned friends once they were no longer useful to him, including the worshipful errand-runners who enabled his gambling habit. This is the Rose who emerges in Keith O’Brien’s new book, “Charlie Hustle: The Rise and Fall of Pete Rose, and the Last Glory Days of Baseball.” A mixture of disillusioned fan’s notes (the author grew up in Cincinnati, rooting for Rose during his prime playing days with the Reds in the 1960s and ’70s), investigative reportage and baseball history, the book paints a picture of an unchecked man-child with no desire to curb his appetites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Stuart A. Thompson
title: What to Know About Tech Companies Using A.I. to Teach Their Own A.I.
description: As artificial intelligence developers run out of data to train their models, they are turning to “synthetic data” — data made by the A.I. itself.
content: OpenAI, Google and other tech companies train their chatbots with huge amounts of data culled from books, Wikipedia articles, news stories and other sources across the internet. But in the future, they hope to use something called synthetic data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Nazaryan
title: Prestigious Medical Journal Ignored Nazi Atrocities, Historians Find
description: The New England Journal of Medicine published an article condemning its own record during World War II.
content: A new article in the New England Journal of Medicine, one of the oldest and most esteemed publications for medical research, criticizes the journal for paying only “superficial and idiosyncratic attention” to the atrocities perpetrated in the name of medical science by the Nazis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The High-I.Q. Nonsense of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
description: His inflated sense of his fitness to lead isn’t just delusional. It’s dangerous.
content: The hubris. The narcissism. The convenient and fraudulent anti-elitism. The out-of-his-mind theories presented as out-of-the-box thinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Berlin Was a Beacon of Artistic Freedom. Gaza Changed Everything.
description: The home of boundary-pushing artists from around the world has been upended by debates about what can and can’t be said about Israel and the war.
content: When the musician Laurie Anderson was beginning her career in the early 1970s, an avant-garde artist who wanted to work at scale had to go abroad — to one place in particular.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Milligan
title: You Don’t Just See a Total Solar Eclipse. You Feel It Completely.
description: An eclipse chaser makes the case for seeing the event in its totality.
content: Almost one year ago, in the middle of the night, I drove from my hometown, Belfast, Northern Ireland, to Dublin to catch an early morning flight to Munich. From there I caught another plane to Bangkok, another to Singapore and yet another to Perth in Western Australia. There, I rented a camper van and began a drive of more than 750 miles north to the town of Exmouth on a remote peninsula on the northwest coast of the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: Put Miso Butter on Everything
description: Add it to chicken thighs, crispy tofu, roasted broccoli, pan-fried mushrooms and pasta. You won’t be able to stop.
content: About once a week, I find myself eating miso butter off a spoon like a deer with a salt lick. (In case you’ve ever wondered what the glamorous life of a Cooking editor looks like, that’s mostly it.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Wayne
title: My Grandfather-in-Law, My Roommate
description: Life lessons from a 97-year-old lawyer of the old school.
content: My wife and I unexpectedly lost our Brooklyn lease in the summer of 2022. With preposterous rents all around us, we decided to save money and postpone our real estate predicament by moving, for one year, into her grandfather’s apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli, Maahil Mohamed and Elke Scholiers
title: Why Time Is Running Out Across the Maldives’ Lovely Little Islands
description: Global tourism brought a modern economy to the country’s thousand islands. For many Maldivians, the teeming capital beckons.
content: To live in the Maldives is to live in one of two worlds. Either you belong to the capital — Malé, a micro-Manhattan in the Indian Ocean — or you are out in “the islands,” among the quietest and most remote villages this side of the Arctic tundra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Donald Trump’s Insatiable Bloodlust
description: Marjorie and Donald, trumpeting the end times.
content: An earthquake. An eclipse. A bridge collapse. A freak blizzard. A biblical flood. Donald Trump leading in battleground states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 300
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 6, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 6, 2024.
content: An article on Friday about simultaneous terrorist attacks by a separatist group in Iran misidentified the location of Sistan and Baluchestan Province, where the attacks occurred. It is in the southeast, not the southwest, of Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Russia Pounds Kharkiv in Deadly Barrage, Straining Ukraine’s Defenses
description: The latest assault on the eastern city killed at least seven people, local authorities said. As Kyiv waits on American aid, Moscow has stepped up bombardments, including using modified “glide bombs.”
content: Russian rockets slammed into residential buildings in Kharkiv before dawn on Saturday, Ukrainian officials said, killing at least seven people and injuring at least 11 more in the latest assault on Ukraine’s second-largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Novels About Uncomfortably Close Families
description: People cross boundaries in Alan Hollinghurst’s “The Spell” and Penelope Lively’s “The Photograph.”
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Biden Reports Major Cash Haul in March as Trump Looks to Catch Up
description: The president and Democrats brought in more than $90 million in March and have more than double what Donald J. Trump and Republicans have on hand.
content: President Biden continued to build on his commanding financial advantage over former President Donald J. Trump, raising more than $90 million in March together with the Democratic Party and affiliated committees, his campaign said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Larry David Has Always Been the ‘Seinfeld’ Finale’s Biggest Defender
description: As “Curb Your Enthusiasm” draws to a close, the “Seinfeld” co-creator gets another shot at ending a TV show.
content: Larry David has long defended the “Seinfeld” finale. He’s often been its lone champion as critics, fans and the cast, including Jerry Seinfeld, have continued to lament the conclusion of one of television’s most successful, enduring sitcoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell and Tristan Spinski
title: A Frozen Pond and a New Way to Experience an Ancient Jewish Ritual in Maine
description: Students from Colby College helped harvest ice from a pond for a new mikvah, or ritual bath, at a synagogue in Waterville.
content: Standing on a frozen pond in western Maine one Sunday morning last month, wearing L.L. Bean boots and a hooded sweatshirt, Rabbi Rachel Isaacs paused to consecrate the ice beneath her feet before she commandeered it for a higher purpose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 4 Expert Tips for Flaky Fish Every Time
description: In the fourth installment of her YouTube series, the cookbook author and chef Sohla El-Waylly will help you make the most flawless fish.
content: Sohla El-Waylly wants you to become an a-fish-ionado. That is, the kind of cook who turns out delicious, flaky fish every time, no matter the style: roasted, braised or battered and fried. In the latest installment of her YouTube series, Cooking 101, she’ll walk you through the best ways to shop for and cook this sometimes-intimidating protein.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Federal Budget Goes From Big Secret to ‘Roadshow’
description: Breaking with Canadian tradition, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has been crisscrossing the country announcing measures from the April 16 budget in advance.
content: Even for a country with a system of government that is prone to keeping things confidential, the secrecy that once surrounded federal budgets stood out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Daddona
title: They Built Three Homes Together. Now She Must Do It Alone.
description: A husband’s sudden death gave a widow time to reflect on the designs of their second homes and how to make one on her own.
content: Sarah-Mai Miller and Heath Miller lived in 10 different houses and apartments in 17 years. The couple owned three of those houses — an 1800s saltbox in Greenport on Long Island and a modern cozy cabin and a glass cabin, both in a town called Milan in upstate New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Book It!
description: Find a comfortable spot to hunker down while we wrangle with Byron Walden’s tough themeless puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the third really gnarly Saturday grid in a row, which makes for a somewhat unsettling pattern. Maybe it’s part of the run-up to this weekend’s American Crossword Puzzle Tournament; maybe it’s another editor’s sadistic streak in Will Shortz’s absence. (What if they’re all like this from now on? It’ll keep this column and its commentariat in business, anyway).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can the Left Be Happy?
description: Comforted by neither God nor history, and hoping vaguely that therapy can take their place.
content: A crucial moment in the development of modern left-wing culture arrived some time in 2013, when Ta-Nehisi Coates, reading books about the ravages and aftermath of World War II by the historians Tony Judt and Timothy Snyder, realized that he didn’t believe in God.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Warns China About Its Exports and Support for Russia
description: Beijing’s economic policies threaten American workers, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen told Vice Premier He Lifeng in the southern city of Guangzhou.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen confronted her Chinese counterpart about China’s surging exports of inexpensive electric vehicles and other green energy goods, saying that they were a threat to American jobs and urging Beijing to scale back its industrial strategy, the U.S. government has said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Who Is Jorge Glas, an Ecuadorean Politician Arrested at Mexico’s Embassy?
description: A former vice president of Ecuador, Jorge Glas had been convicted of bribery in two separate cases. He had fled to the Mexican Embassy in Quito after facing more embezzlement charges.
content: Mexico has severed diplomatic relations with Ecuador after Ecuadorean police officers on Friday arrested Jorge Glas, an Ecuadorean politician who had been granted refuge in Mexico’s Embassy in Quito.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Eclipse Mania
description: There’s still reason to get excited, even if you’re not convinced by the hype.
content: On Monday, the moon will steal between the Earth and the sun, a total solar eclipse in North America. The path of totality, the strip of the continent where the moon will completely obscure the sun, begins in Mazatlán, Mexico, crosses over more than a dozen U.S. states, from Texas to Maine, and ends in Newfoundland, Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Jamie Kelter Davis
title: Fierce Races Loom With Wisconsin’s New Political Maps
description: The new legislative maps reflect a near split between Republican- and Democratic-leaning districts. For more than a decade, earlier maps had helped Republicans hold power.
content: Yee Leng Xiong, a 29-year-old nonprofit executive, has been an elected official in Wisconsin since he was a teenager. From a north central county known for ginseng farming and downhill skiing, he has served on the local school board, the Marathon County Board and the village board of trustees in Weston, population 15,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
title: Gaza War Turns Spotlight on Long Pipeline of U.S. Weapons to Israel
description: President Biden sends arms to Israel under an Obama-era $38 billion aid agreement that runs until 2026. Israel’s purchases include the types of bombs dropped in Gaza.
content: In the fall of 2016, the Obama administration sealed a major military agreement with Israel that committed the United States to giving the country $38 billion in arms over 10 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Thompson Walker
title: A Fictional Haven So Idyllic You Don’t Even Need Money. What Could Go Wrong?
description: In “A Better World,” a family hoping to escape their dangerous reality gets invited to an exclusive town only to discover that it’s not as peaceful as it seems.
content: Early in Sarah Langan’s lively and satirical fifth novel, “A Better World,” a woman whose family has been handpicked to move to an idyllic small town begins to suspect that the place is too good to be true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang, Cade Metz and Stuart A. Thompson
title: Four Takeaways on the Race to Amass Data for A.I.
description: To make artificial intelligence systems more powerful, tech companies need online data to feed the technology. Here’s what to know.
content: Online data has long been a valuable commodity. For years, Meta and Google have used data to target their online advertising. Netflix and Spotify have used it to recommend more movies and music. Political candidates have turned to data to learn which groups of voters to train their sights on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Sheff
title: A Mother’s Devastating Memoir of Losing Her Adult Son
description: In “Fi,” Alexandra Fuller describes the sudden death of her 21-year-old.
content: Alexandra Fuller learned the art of denial from her gloriously dysfunctional parents. “‘Mum’s having a bit of a wobbly,’ Dad would explain, that dangerous British habit of underestimating the gravity of any given situation until you were eating the last sled dog and writing your final diary entries.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Hurubie Meko
title: Arrests Expose Rift Between N.Y.P.D. and ‘Violence Interrupters’
description: An outreach worker trained to intervene in street conflicts was hospitalized after he and a colleague were arrested amid an altercation with the police.
content: For years, New York City has employed a two-pronged approach to reducing gun violence, relying on the police and on the publicly funded conflict mediators known as violence interrupters, who try to defuse disputes before they escalate, including into gunfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Baumgarten
title: How a Vacant Lot Became Our Own Dirtbag Narnia
description: In the Kensington neighborhood of Philadelphia, a group of neighbors made a makeshift community oasis.
content: On a quiet street in the Kensington neighborhood of Philadelphia, just a few steps from my back door, is a vacant lot that my wife, Anne, and I share with our neighbors. This patch of dirty ground was once three single-family homes. Bit by bit, rains have washed away the soil, revealing corners of the buildings’ foundations and the occasional broken brick and shard of glass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Make Room, Tennis, Pickleball and Squash. Here Comes Padel.
description: The sport is played with a racket on a court with a net, but watch out for those bouncing shots from the back wall. Reporters take a look at the padel scene in New York City.
content: I first learned about padel last summer, when my partner sent me a photo from a small court during a visit to Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Flynn Berry
title: When a Couple’s Paradise Honeymoon Became a Gothic Mystery
description: Scarlett Thomas’s latest novel, “The Sleepwalkers,” recounts the tale of a couple’s disastrous getaway, told through letters, transcripts and more.
content: My arguments on vacation have always been dreary — disagreements with my mom on how far to walk before setting up a beach umbrella, squabbles with friends over where to eat — but other people’s vacation arguments are sinister and seductive. Or at least they are in books, and especially in Scarlett Thomas’s 11th novel, “The Sleepwalkers,” as a couple’s trip abroad in a dazzling, dangerous territory (a landscape familiar from Highsmith and Hitchcock, “La Piscine” and Françoise Sagan) is derailed by latent tensions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: As Gen X-ers Inch Toward Retirement, They’re Considering Where to Live
description: The oldest members of Generation X are several years from stopping work, but some are already seeking homes that will suit their later years.
content: When they were raising their four children, Billy and Erin Shipley had space for their family to grow: a two-story, five-bedroom house in Sugar Land, Texas, with a large yard and a pool. But as the children became adults and moved out, the second floor was deserted and maintaining the lawn and pool became a burden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon, Isabella Kwai and Julie Turkewitz
title: Mexico Breaks Diplomatic Ties With Ecuador After Arrest at Embassy
description: Jorge Glas, a former vice president, had taken refuge at the Mexican Embassy in Ecuador’s capital. Mexico’s president called his arrest a violation of international law.
content: The Ecuadorean police on Friday night arrested a politician who had taken refuge in the Mexican Embassy in Quito, after what Mexico described as a forced entry that violated the country’s sovereignty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Power Shut Off to 55,000 in Colorado to Prevent Wind-Fueled Wildfires
description: Xcel Energy said the outage would affect parts of six counties and last until at least noon on Sunday. Winds could reach 100 miles per hour.
content: A power company in Colorado announced on Saturday that it was cutting power to roughly 55,000 customers over wildfire concerns as powerful winds, some as high as 100 miles per hour, battered the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: The Eclipse That Ended a War and Shook the Gods Forever
description: Thales, a Greek philosopher 2,600 years ago, is celebrated for predicting a famous solar eclipse and founding what came to be known as science.
content: In the spring of 585 B.C. in the Eastern Mediterranean, the moon came out of nowhere to hide the face of the sun, turning day into night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How Zach Cherry, Actor From ‘Severance,’ Spends His Sundays
description: Before he hits the stage for an improv show, Mr. Cherry cuddles with his rescue dog, Shrek, battles his wife in video games and heads to the movies.
content: Zach Cherry warns that his Sundays are “pretty boring” — with the caveat that boring, for him, means a wild, 90-minute improv comedy extravaganza of nerdy jokes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart and Rose Callahan
title: The Orchid Show After Dark, Where Green Thumbs and Plant Killers Mingle
description: After hours, the New York Botanical Garden becomes the lushest bar in town.
content: It was Saturday night in the Bronx, and as a lively, colorful crowd sipped vodka cocktails underneath dramatic palm fronds, the word people kept whispering was “phalaenopsis.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Teen Drug Use Habits Are Changing, For the Good. With Caveats.
description: Dr. Nora Volkow, who leads the National Institutes of Drug Abuse, would like the public to know things are getting better. Mostly.
content: Historically speaking, it’s not a bad time to be the liver of a teenager. Or the lungs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
title: Iran vows revenge at a funeral for commanders killed in an Israeli airstrike.
description: There are precedents for a forceful response by Iran to the Israeli airstrike in Syria on Monday that killed senior commanders and other officers of Iran’s elite Quds Force.
content: There are precedents for a forceful response by Iran to the Israeli airstrike in Syria on Monday that killed senior commanders and other officers of Iran’s elite Quds Force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz, Cecilia Kang, Sheera Frenkel, Stuart A. Thompson and Nico Grant
title: How Tech Giants Cut Corners to Harvest Data for A.I.
description: OpenAI, Google and Meta ignored corporate policies, altered their own rules and discussed skirting copyright law as they sought online information to train their newest artificial intelligence systems.
content: In late 2021, OpenAI faced a supply problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr, Katie Van Syckle, Nina Westervelt and Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet
title: Leonardo DiCaprio, Tracee Ellis Ross and Gayle King Hit New York Art Parties
description: This week, the New Museum gala drew a crowd to Lower Manhattan and the MoMA Black Arts Council mingled in Midtown, as the Spring benefit season kicked into gear.
content: Outside the Staten Island Ferry terminal in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday night, the wind was howling as broken umbrellas blew across South Street like urban tumbleweeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Anna Betts
title: Another Israeli Hostage’s Body Recovered, the Death Angering His Family
description: Like the families of other hostages, they are outraged that the Israeli government has yet to reach a deal to halt the fighting and bring home loved ones held in Gaza.
content: The Israeli military said on Saturday that it had recovered the body of an Israeli hostage who was abducted during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack, almost six months after he was taken hostage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anders Nilsen
title: Why Richard Serra’s Art Will Outlive Us All
description: The great American artist was born in 1938 and died last week, but his work transcends time.
content: The great American artist was born in 1938 and died last week, but his work transcends time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin and Lazaro Gamio
title: Power by Proxy: How Iran Shapes the Mideast
description: A guide to the armed groups that let Iran extend its influence throughout the region.
content: A guide to the armed groups that let Iran extend its influence throughout the region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How ‘All in the Family’ Explains Biden’s Strength Among Seniors
description: Yesterday’s hippies have become today’s seniors — and they’re still voting Democratic.
content: Yesterday’s hippies have become today’s seniors — and they’re still voting Democratic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker, Anjali Singhvi, Helmuth Rosales, David W. Chen and Elena Shao
title: Dozens of Major Bridges Lack Shields to Block Wayward Ships
description: The collapse of the Key Bridge in Baltimore has prompted a reassessment of critical bridges around the country that may be similarly vulnerable to a ship strike.
content: The collapse of the Key Bridge in Baltimore has prompted a reassessment of critical bridges around the country that may be similarly vulnerable to a ship strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikolay Nikolov, Jan Ransom and Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: Our Reporter on a Case of Glaring Neglect on Rikers
description: In 2019, eight correction officers and a captain at Rikers Island stood by for seven minutes and 51 seconds as Nicholas Feliciano, an 18-year-old, was hanging in a jail cell, video footage obtained by The New York Times shows. Feliciano suffered severe brain damage and requires round-the-clock care. New York City paid more than $28 million to settle a lawsuit filed by the family of Feliciano.
content: In 2019, eight correction officers and a captain at Rikers Island stood by for seven minutes and 51 seconds as Nicholas Feliciano, an 18-year-old, was hanging in a jail cell, video footage obtained by The New York Times shows. Feliciano suffered severe brain damage and requires round-the-clock care. New York City paid more than $28 million to settle a lawsuit filed by the family of Feliciano.
source.name: The New York Times
